natural problem: Alex needs to catch a train. The train arrives randomly some time between 1:00 and 2:00, waits for 10 minutes, and then leaves. If Alex also arrives randomly between 1:00 and 2:00, what is the probability that the train will be there when Alex arrives?
natural solution: We put the time the train arrives on the $y$-axis and the time  Alex arrives on the $x$-axis, and shade in the region where Alex arrives while the train is there. [asy] fill((0,0)--(60,60)--(60,50)--(10,0)--cycle, gray(.7));

draw((0,0)--(60,0), Arrow); draw((0,0)--(0,60), Arrow); label("1:00", (0,0), SW); label("2:00", (60,0), S); label("2:00", (0,60), W); [/asy] The probability that Alex arrives while the train is at the station is the ratio of the shaded area to the whole square.

If we divide the axes into 60 units, the shaded region can be split up into a triangle of area 50 square units and a parallelogram of area 500 square units, and the whole square has an area of 3600 square units.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P_train P_alex :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "P_train t = 1/60"
and h1 : "t \<in> {0..60}"
and h2 : "P_alex t = 1/60"
and h3 : "t \<in> {0..60}"
and h4 : "\<forall>t. 0 \<le> t \<and> t \<le> 60 \<longrightarrow> (P_train t * P_alex t = 1/3600)"
shows  "probability (\<lambda>t. P_train t * P_alex t) {t. t \<in> {0..60} \<and> t \<le> 60 - 10} = 11/72"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Alex needs to catch a train. The train arrives randomly some time between 1:00 and 2:00, waits for 10 minutes, and then leaves. If Alex also arrives randomly between 1:00 and 2:00, what is the probability that the train will be there when Alex arrives? The final Answer is \frac{11}{72}
 ### Proof
 We put the time the train arrives on the $y$-axis and the time  Alex arrives on the $x$-axis, and shade in the region where Alex arrives while the train is there. [asy] fill((0,0)--(60,60)--(60,50)--(10,0)--cycle, gray(.7));
 draw((0,0)--(60,0), Arrow); draw((0,0)--(0,60), Arrow); label("1:00", (0,0), SW); label("2:00", (60,0), S); label("2:00", (0,60), W); [/asy] The probability that Alex arrives while the train is at the station is the ratio of the shaded area to the whole square.
 If we divide the axes into 60 units, the shaded region can be split up into a triangle of area 50 square units and a parallelogram of area 500 square units, and the whole square has an area of 3600 square units.
 The ratio is $550/3600=\boxed{\frac{11}{72}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes P_train P_alex :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "P_train t = 1/60"
and h1 : "t \<in> {0..60}"
and h2 : "P_alex t = 1/60"
and h3 : "t \<in> {0..60}"
and h4 : "\<forall>t. 0 \<le> t \<and> t \<le> 60 \<longrightarrow> (P_train t * P_alex t = 1/3600)"
shows  "probability (\<lambda>t. P_train t * P_alex t) {t. t \<in> {0..60} \<and> t \<le> 60 - 10} = 11/72"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: A train and Alex are both moving at a constant speed, with the probability density functions for their positions being $P_{train}(t) = \frac{1}{60}$ and $P_{alex}(t) = \frac{1}{60}$, respectively, for $0 \leq t \leq 60$. It is also given that $P_{train}(t) \cdot P_{alex}(t) = \frac{1}{3600}$ for all $0 \leq t \leq 60$. What is the probability that Alex will be within 10 units of distance from the train after 60 time units? The final answer is $\frac{11}{72}$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "probability (\<lambda>x. 1 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 2) = 1"
and h1 : "probability (\<lambda>x. 1 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 2 - 1/6) = 5 / 6"
and h2 : "probability (\<lambda>x. 1 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 2 + 1/6) = 7 / 6"
and h3 : "probability (\<lambda>x y. 1 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 2 \<and> 1 \<le> y \<and> y \<le> 2 \<and> x \<le> y \<and> y \<le> x + 1/6) = 11 / 72"
shows  "probability (\<lambda>x. \<exists>y. 1 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 2 \<and> 1 \<le> y \<and> y \<le> 2 \<and> x \<le> y \<and> y \<le> x + 1/6) = 11 / 72"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Alex needs to catch a train. The train arrives randomly some time between 1:00 and 2:00, waits for 10 minutes, and then leaves. If Alex also arrives randomly between 1:00 and 2:00, what is the probability that the train will be there when Alex arrives? The final Answer is \frac{11}{72}
 ### Proof
 We put the time the train arrives on the $y$-axis and the time  Alex arrives on the $x$-axis, and shade in the region where Alex arrives while the train is there. [asy] fill((0,0)--(60,60)--(60,50)--(10,0)--cycle, gray(.7));
 draw((0,0)--(60,0), Arrow); draw((0,0)--(0,60), Arrow); label("1:00", (0,0), SW); label("2:00", (60,0), S); label("2:00", (0,60), W); [/asy] The probability that Alex arrives while the train is at the station is the ratio of the shaded area to the whole square.
 If we divide the axes into 60 units, the shaded region can be split up into a triangle of area 50 square units and a parallelogram of area 500 square units, and the whole square has an area of 3600 square units.
 The ratio is $550/3600=\boxed{\frac{11}{72}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes probability :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "probability (\<lambda>x. 1 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 2) = 1"
and h1 : "probability (\<lambda>x. 1 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 2 - 1/6) = 5 / 6"
and h2 : "probability (\<lambda>x. 1 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 2 + 1/6) = 7 / 6"
and h3 : "probability (\<lambda>x y. 1 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 2 \<and> 1 \<le> y \<and> y \<le> 2 \<and> x \<le> y \<and> y \<le> x + 1/6) = 11 / 72"
shows  "probability (\<lambda>x. \<exists>y. 1 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 2 \<and> 1 \<le> y \<and> y \<le> 2 \<and> x \<le> y \<and> y \<le> x + 1/6) = 11 / 72"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: A probability function is defined on the interval $[1, 2]$. The probability of a number being in the interval $[1, 2 - \frac{1}{6}]$ is $\frac{5}{6}$, and the probability of a number being in the interval $[1, 2 + \frac{1}{6}]$ is $\frac{7}{6}$. What is the probability that there exists a number $y$ in the interval $[1, 2]$ such that $x \le y \le x + \frac{1}{6}$, where $x$ is also in the interval $[1, 2]$? The final answer is $\frac{11}{72}$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x. P x = 1 / 60"
and h1 : "integral {1..2} P = 1"
and h2 : "integral {1..2} (\<lambda>x. integral {x..x+10/60} P) = p"
shows  "p = 11 / 72"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Alex needs to catch a train. The train arrives randomly some time between 1:00 and 2:00, waits for 10 minutes, and then leaves. If Alex also arrives randomly between 1:00 and 2:00, what is the probability that the train will be there when Alex arrives? The final Answer is \frac{11}{72}

theorem
fixes P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x. P x = 1 / 60"
and h1 : "integral {1..2} P = 1"
and h2 : "integral {1..2} (\<lambda>x. integral {x..x+10/60} P) = p"
shows  "p = 11 / 72"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Given a function $P(x) = \frac{1}{60}$, find the value of $p$ for which the integral of the function over the interval $[1, 2]$ is equal to $1$, and the integral of the function over the interval $[x, x+\frac{10}{60}]$ for each $x$ in the interval $[1, 2]$ is equal to $p$. The final answer is $\frac{11}{72}$.

If the train arrives before Alex and stays for 10 minutes, find the probability that Alex meets the train. The final answer is $\frac{11}{72}$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "uniform_continuous_on {1..2} P"
and h1 : "integral {1..2} (\<lambda>x. P x) = 1"
and h2 : "integral {1..2} (\<lambda>x. P x * (\<lambda>t. if x + 10 / 60 \<le> t \<and> t \<le> 2 then 1 else 0) x) = p"
shows  "p = 11 / 72"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Alex needs to catch a train. The train arrives randomly some time between 1:00 and 2:00, waits for 10 minutes, and then leaves. If Alex also arrives randomly between 1:00 and 2:00, what is the probability that the train will be there when Alex arrives? The final Answer is \frac{11}{72}
 ### Proof
 We put the time the train arrives on the $y$-axis and the time  Alex arrives on the $x$-axis, and shade in the region where Alex arrives while the train is there. [asy] fill((0,0)--(60,60)--(60,50)--(10,0)--cycle, gray(.7));
 draw((0,0)--(60,0), Arrow); draw((0,0)--(0,60), Arrow); label("1:00", (0,0), SW); label("2:00", (60,0), S); label("2:00", (0,60), W); [/asy] The probability that Alex arrives while the train is at the station is the ratio of the shaded area to the whole square.
 If we divide the axes into 60 units, the shaded region can be split up into a triangle of area 50 square units and a parallelogram of area 500 square units, and the whole square has an area of 3600 square units.
 The ratio is $550/3600=\boxed{\frac{11}{72}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "uniform_continuous_on {1..2} P"
and h1 : "integral {1..2} (\<lambda>x. P x) = 1"
and h2 : "integral {1..2} (\<lambda>x. P x * (\<lambda>t. if x + 10 / 60 \<le> t \<and> t \<le> 2 then 1 else 0) x) = p"
shows  "p = 11 / 72"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Let $P(x)$ be a function that is uniformly continuous on the interval $[1, 2]$. Suppose the integral of $P(x)$ from $1$ to $2$ is equal to $1$. Let $p$ be the integral of $P(x)$ times an indicator function that is equal to $1$ if $x + \frac{10}{60} \leq t \leq 2$ and $0$ otherwise, from $1$ to $2$. Find the value of $p$. The final answer is $\frac{11}{72}$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "P x = ((11 - x) / 72) when (x \<ge> 1 \<and> x \<le> 2)"
and h1 : "P x = 0 when (x < 1 \<or> x > 2)"
shows  "integral (\<lambda> x. P x) 1 2 = 11 / 72"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Alex needs to catch a train. The train arrives randomly some time between 1:00 and 2:00, waits for 10 minutes, and then leaves. If Alex also arrives randomly between 1:00 and 2:00, what is the probability that the train will be there when Alex arrives? The final Answer is \frac{11}{72}

 If we divide the axes into 60 units, the shaded region can be split up into a triangle of area 50 square units and a parallelogram of area 500 square units, and the whole square has an area of 3600 square units.
 The ratio is $550/3600=\boxed{\frac{11}{72}}$.
 *)

fixes P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"

a_9.informal problem: Let $P(x) = \frac{11 - x}{72}$ when $1 \leq x \leq 2$, and $P(x) = 0$ when $x < 1$ or $x > 2$. Find the definite integral of $P(x)$ from $1$ to $2$. The final answer is $\frac{11}{72}$.
